text:
Thank you for the opportunity
to conduct this interview with you.

Please briefly
introduce your company?

We're talking about AXA here,
that's AXA here in Germany,

AXA Konzern AG with all
associated insurance companies.

We are part of
a global insurance group
with headquarters in France.
We represent about 10%
of this global insurance group,

which is represented
in about 60 countries,
with roughly 8000 employees,
permanent employees, in Germany,
plus our sales force.

In industry jargon,
we are a full-range insurer.

That means we have products
across all product ranges

from life insurer and health
insurer up to property insurer,

we have everything
and also all customer groups,
from private customers

to institutional
and corporate customers.

Who are you personally, what is
your role in the company?

My name is Sascha,
Sascha Noack, 46 years old,

the Chief Security Officer
for AXA Germany.

Responsible
for a wide range of areas,

things like Operation Resilience,
business continuity,

physical security, and of course,
information security.

Yes, and I'm Marc,
Marc Becker, 44 years old,

now a little more
than ten years at AXA.

My journey has led me
from finance

and risk management,
to controlling.

Most recently, I was responsible
for auditing here in the company.

And now for about
2.5 years in IT.

The IT department is well-represented
with 700 staff members.

And I'm responsible for that
the central area
with about 280 employees.
It's called IT Geo.

The three letters
stand for G, as in governance,

i.e., everything related
to regulatory legal matters

and organizational
responsibility.
The E stands for enablement.

That means
central support services

such as HR Master,
Project Manager, etc.

And the O is for Operations, which
represents classic IT operations.
What is the vision of AXA?

Let's just start with the vision
of the AXA Security Unit.

Three words are important for us:
care, protect, alert.

We take care of things,
we protect the company,
and we are open with each other.
That is, if we find something,

we're not afraid
to report it,

but we report it and process
issues together.

And that spirit of protection
Sascha is describing
also fits into the overall context.

Insurance, insurance
products are those products

which provide protection in case
of a crisis, in problem cases,
in situations of a financial nature
or in case of other problems.

So, our mission
in that sense, as a company,
as an insurance company,

is to provide our customers with
security in one form or another.

And in todayâ€™s world,
to make that possible,

from the product
to the service provision behind it,

IT is a very central partner
in this company,
without which nothing works.

And so that we can also be
a secure partner

for our customers
at any time,

that implicitly means
that IT also needs to be
an available partner here in-house

for all other company
functions.
So in this respect,

security, reliability,
availability is our motto.

What is something the world
may not know about AXA?

So, what I think is very,
very exciting about us

is the open interactions between us,
this whole cultural change,

that we've gone through
over the last few years.

We talk about everything
very transparently.
We have an informal culture.

I think these are areas where we
have really developed
over the past few years.

And they help us
in today's world.

And the other thing is, one might
associate the concept of security

or the insurance industry
relatively quickly

with keywords like traditional,
reserved,

careful, inhibited
or similar to that.

And I think precisely that
is a key difference

or something that makes AXA
stand out in the insurance industry.

Because we don't see it
as a contradiction
to be pioneering ourselves.

We want to go along with the
changing times in every way,

whether it's cultural,
as Sascha mentioned,

be on top of things
technically

and to learn to move
into the future,

instead of possibly being outpaced
by the technology.

Could one say that this
also moved you...
towards working with the cloud,

like you said,
we're looking at this technology

and assessing it in terms of risk
but without prejudice?

I think historically,
if we look back a little bit,
what was security
like in the past?
We used to be the nay-sayers.

729914We looked at things
and said,
"You can't do that,"

and that was the end
of the conversation.

What we've developed
over the years
is the whole topic of risk culture.

Of course, sometimes
we can't do things,

but we can of course
also take a risk-oriented view.

That is,
we don't have to say no in general,

but we ask, how high
is the risk, actually?
Regarding the Cloud:

What kinds of data can I
upload to the cloud?

What can I
just try out

without directly violating the law
or something similar?

And yes, what you said
that applies to us,

because when the topic of the cloud
became more and more pressing,
it was very obvious to us

that it would be integral
to the future

and would replace some
other technologies.

Thatâ€™s why it was no
question at all for us
to not be in the cloud,

but merely the question
"How do we get there?

How quickly do we get there,
to what extent?

How quickly do we get there,
to what extent?"
To then build another pillar,

and, in dialogue,
with our colleagues

who can assess
security and risk issues

so that, despite moving forward
into the unknown,

we can, at the same time,
ensure that all-important security.

Did you have any
specific challenges at the time?

where you said, "Okay,
we need to open up for this reason.

we need to open evaluate the cloud
for this reason."
Well, for us,

the classic core IT,
as we call it,

had set very strict
framework conditions.

The typical examples
are the big releases.

We couldn't just change
parts of our IT landscape

individually
or in a needs-based way.

It had placed an absolute limit
on how fast we could
implement new features and needs

in the products,
in the systems.

Just this question
of speed
and needs orientation
had absolutely reached its limit,
which is why we needed new ways.

Now you,
as a regulated company,

are, of course, in a very,
very unique situation.
Which legal framework conditions

did you have to consider
on your path to using the cloud?

Naturally we're under the Federal
Financial Supervisory Authority

i.e. we follow the Supervisory
Requirements for

IT in Insurance (VAIT), which
places demands on IT.

We are operators
of critical infrastructure.

That means we are subject to
the IT Security Act.

There are also
a lot of requirements there.

And of course, the GDPR
is also in the mix
to see how far can we go
with personal data.

The challenge is to follow all
of these laws at the same time.

We've brought in data protection,
we've brought in IT.

Everyone we've identified
as stakeholders.

And looked at
what the requirements are

and how do we adhere
to all of them?

And what can you use to simply
try out using the cloud?
You can perhaps add

that the regulations
that we come run into,

which are absolutely relevant to us
and critical,

are often caught up more in
classical ways of thinking.
So, in the VAIT,

which is one of the most relevant
regulatory laws for us,
you actually find the assumption

that there is a separation between
development and operations.

Do you want to be more
future-oriented, agile?

We are working with
so-called DevOps teams

where, of course,
the development of software
is combined with operations.

Consequently, the traditional
division of tasks

that is assumed
is not there at all.

So now we need to
take the next step and say:
If the regulations, for example,

require double checks,
which is traditionally achieved
automatically by separating
development and operations,
but we don't meet the prerequisites

due to the structure of
our organization, then we need to

consider the
underlying principle and ask:

"Yeah, how do we implement
this double check anyway
as a security measure even if,

it's not there
in a traditional sense?"

You've chosen
a risk-oriented culture.

And in terms of technology,
you are open
to the new ways.
But you're regulated.

Can you tell us a little bit about
how you proceeded, in-house,

and approached the
Supervisory Authority?

So, that's really
the whole issue of cultural change.

This open interaction
where you donâ€™t say,

"Now you need to go to Data
Protection, you go to Security."

The departments and IT Dept.
get sent back and forth.

Instead, you talk
openly to each other.

You really look at
what you want to achieve.

Not with the idea that this
or that can't work.

Instead, it's
how far can we go?

So we say, where do the
regulatory requirements apply

and what can we do
to at least try this out?

So, for example, I really appreciate
that, in the company,

we don't have just
the traditional:

"I'll try something
with my team".

We present it and
submit a request to release
what we've built.

And then we get surprised
by everything

that may not fulfill
the requirements.

Instead, with a pioneering spirit
from the start, we try to

enable, i.e. to consider
what is possible overall.

And this system, which has
proven itself within the company,

we have also used it
on a large scale.

So, when we were taking our
first steps towards the cloud,

we proactively
approached the regulator

and didnâ€™t wait to be
inspected at some point, just

to learn what we could
and couldn't do.

Instead we just respected
and acknowledged
that even a regulator needs time

to get used to and understand
new framework conditions.

Of course,
because it affects us,

we are usually
one step further,

just because we have gained
more experience.
And it pays

to treat the regulator
as a partner as well,
to share knowledge and, as a result,

similar to a second line
that Sascha represents,

to get a certain openness
from the regulator as well,
and a solution-oriented approach

instead of a traditional approval
or acceptance.

Now the change
when you go to the cloud

is something that takes place
very, very slowly.
It may be that you do it

to get two, three, four customer
systems into the cloud.

But actually you want to
keep your data center.

Or there are other ways
that say,

"Okay, we're learning,
we're evolving."
What is the path for AXA?

Although we have to
feel our way forward

a bit at a time in terms of
technology and skills,

we still asked the
question very early:

Will this only be a supplement
to our technology stack?

Or do we want to
base an essential pillar on it

and, as a result,
give up other pillars,
in order to grow over all.

We've chosen
the latter.

So, already in 2016
the AXA group
worldwide made the decision

to go all the way
into the cloud.

Sometimes
alongside the mainframe,

which is an absolute necessity
in our industry.

But with this path,
we are naturally also proceeding
in a very forward-looking

and, at the same time,
safety-conscious manner.

So, as an example, our first
application that was in the cloud,

I can still remember,
was our black board.

But it worked
and we learned from it.
And thatâ€™s the first step.

Today, what we try is
much larger in scope.
And when you look at Core IT,
we have now moved 80%

of our Core IT
to the cloud.
You've made a cultural change,

which can be seen, for example,
in the DevOps approaches.

But at the same time, you still
have to focus on security.

So, to what extent has
your ISMS, your security management,
changed along the way.

2016 â€“ decision
to move to the cloud.
And today.

I think
anybody can imagine a

data center that has
grown up over time.

On one side, you have
the mainframe.
You still have your old treasures.

The cloud's advantage
is really:
I have a single level of security.

I can respond relatively quickly
to new demands.

Whether those are there are new
vulnerabilities outside, or similar.

In Core IT, this is
of course significantly more complex.

Because I have
the whole landscape
that you can imagine.

Unlike the cloud, where
I have a complete overview.
And I also think

that technology used to
develop in waves.

There was a whole wave
of a more constant technology.
Then there was a new wave.
And that was also how

the interaction with security and
other supervising entities was.

That, basically, in business
you worked on the next level.

And then Security was added
after a delay.

Then they also had
to gain this expertise.

And then at some point came
the confirmation: the step is good.

Todayâ€™s technology
no longer comes in waves.

Rather, we discover something new
every day.

So, we're much more continuous
in terms of technical evolution.
This also changes the interactions

in the interplay of units
like Security.

Namely, that they just don't
follow after the waves with a delay,

but are already with you
at every step

and we're almost synchronized in
terms of skills and content.

That means that Security is
an integral part

of every project decision,
of every migration?

Exactly. This overall overview,
it's significantly easier.

Plus, with the cloud
you can

access this information
directly yourself,

instead of the traditional sense
of needing to request it.

So now you're about to take a
step with AXA,
which sounded like:

the plan is actually
to go completely to the cloud.
When do you say:

These are the coming issues
that we're already working on

today as we know
it's good for end customers,

it's good for your employees,
it's good for you yourself?
Is there a bit of a vision?
There are many customers

who don't know anything
about the cloud

and just hear, "My data
are now in the cloud."

To really tell the customer:
The cloud is exactly the right way.

We can take care of your data,
your data are secure.

And part of my role is being the
traditional IT Operations Manager.
Even though, organizationally,
we don't have that anymore.
But to know what's going on -
as simple as that may sound,

that is not a given
in core IT.

I have so many components
that just continue to exist and run.

But then when there's a failure,
which is what
makes an IT Operations Manager's
life difficult,

it's always like searching for
a needle in a haystack.
Iâ€™m looking forward to

having continuous
monitoring and tracing
across the entire IT landscape,
to really focus our work
entirely on

further development,
focused on stability,

or significantly minimize the area
of problem solving, incident
problem management,

because we can problem solve
in a targeted manner.

That is a wonderful
conclusion to our conversation.

Thank you very much
for your openness,

for the topics
we were able to address.
Thank you very much.
